content.text: Explain briefly how to measure to the centre of the pendulum bob as accurately as possible
Calculate, and record in Table 1.1, the period \(T\) of the pendulum. The period is the time for one complete oscillation
Calculate, and record in Table 1.1, the value of \(T^2\)
He repeats the procedure using \(l\) values of \(60.0 \text{cm}\), \(70.0 \text{cm}\), \(80.0 \text{cm}\) and \(90.0 \text{cm}\). The readings and results are shown in Table 1.1
The student adjusts the length of the pendulum until the distance \(l\), measured from the bottom of the clamp supporting the pendulum to the centre of the pendulum bob, is \(50.0 \text{cm}\)
He displaces the bob slightly and releases it so that it swings. Fig. 1.2 shows one complete oscillation of the pendulum
He measures and records the time \(t\) for 20 complete oscillations
Plot a graph of \(T^2 /\mathrm{s}^2\) (y-axis) against \(l / \mathrm{cm}\) (x-axis). Start the \(T^2 /\mathrm{s}^2\) axis at a convenient value close to the minimum value of \(T^2 /\mathrm{s}^2\)
Determine the gradient G of the graph. Show clearly on the graph how you obtained the necessary information
G =
Explain briefly why timing 20 oscillations gives a more accurate result for the period \(T\) than timing 1 oscillation
A student investigates the period of a pendulum. Fig. 1.1 and Fig. 1.2 show the set-up
Fig. 1.2
On Fig. 2.1, draw a voltmeter connected to measure the potential difference (p.d.) across the lamp.
Record the readings shown in Fig. 2.2 and Fig. 2.3
Calculate the resistance \(R_{1}\) of lamp L. Use the equation \(R_{1} = \frac{V_{1}}{I_{1}}\) . Include the unit
The student places a sliding contact S on the resistance wire CE as close as possible to point C
She measures the potential difference \(V_{1}\) across lamp L and the current \(I_{1}\) in the circuit. The readings are shown in Fig. 2.2 and Fig. 2.3
Fig. 2.3
She places the sliding contact S on the resistance wire as close as possible to point D. Point D is at the mid-point of the resistance wire
She measures the potential difference \(V_{2}\) across lamp L
She places the sliding contact S on the resistance wire as close as possible to point E
She measures the potential difference \(V_{3}\) across lamp L
She measures the current \(I_{3}\) in the circuit
Calculate the resistance \(R_{3}\) of lamp L. Use the equation \(R_{3} = \frac{V_{3}}{I_{3}}\) . Include the unit
Complete the following statements, referring to your practical experience and the results
1. As the length of resistance wire included in the circuit is increased, the brightness of the
lamp
2. As the length of resistance wire included in the circuit is increased, the resistance of the
lamp
A variable resistor can be used in this type of experiment in place of the resistance wire
Draw a circuit diagram to show a variable resistor in place of the resistance wire. Include the ammeter and the voltmeter in your diagram
A student investigates the resistance of a lamp. She uses the circuit shown in Fig. 2.1
The thermometer in Fig. 3.2 shows the room temperature \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\) at the beginning of the experiment. Record \(\theta_{\mathrm{R}}\)
\(\theta_{\mathrm{R}} =\)   .........  \(^\circ \mathrm{C}\)
The student uses a measuring cylinder to pour \(200 \text{cm}^3\) of hot water into the beaker
He records in Table 3.1 the temperature \(\theta\) of the hot water at time \(t = 0\)
He measures, and records in Table 3.1, the water temperature every 30 s
Complete the time \(t\) column in Table 3.1
Calculate the decrease in temperature \(\Delta \theta_{1}\) between \(t = 0\) and \(t = 180 \text{s}\)
Calculate the average rate of cooling \(C_1\) of the water using the equation \(C_1 = \frac{\Delta \theta_1}{\Delta t}\) , where \(\Delta t = 180 \text{s}\). Include the unit
The student empties the beaker
He pours warm water into the same beaker
He records in Table 3.2 the temperature \(\theta\) of the warm water at time \(t = 0\)
He measures, and records in Table 3.2, the water temperature every \(30 \text{s}\)
Using Table 3.2, calculate the decrease in temperature \(\Delta \theta_{2}\) between \(t = 0\) and \(t = 90 \text{s}\)
Calculate the average rate of cooling \(C_2\) of the water using the equation \(C_2 = \frac{\Delta \theta_2}{\Delta t}\) , where \(\Delta t = 90 \text{s}\)
A student suggests that the rate of cooling of water depends on the initial temperature of the water
Write a conclusion about the effect of the initial temperature of water on the rate of cooling of the water, based on the results. Justify your conclusion by reference to values from the results
conclusion
justification
State two requirements when reading the volume of water in a measuring cylinder in order to obtain an accurate result
Suggest two possible variables that the student should keep constant
A student investigates the effect of the starting temperature on the cooling rate of water
Fig. 3.1 shows the apparatus used
A student investigates the horizontal distance travelled by a metal ball after it rolls off the end of a plastic track. Fig. 4.1 shows the set-up
The ball rolls down a plastic track. The left-hand side of the track is fixed. The right-hand side can be adjusted so that the ball comes off the track at different angles
The student measures the horizontal distance that the ball travels from the right-hand end of the track to the point that it hits the floor
Plan an experiment to investigate how the horizontal distance travelled by the metal ball depends on the angle that the right-hand end of the track makes with the bench
The following apparatus is available to the student:
track with stand, boss and clamp
selection of metal balls
Other apparatus normally available in a school laboratory can also be used
In your plan, you should:
list any additional apparatus required
explain briefly how you would do the investigation, including the measurements you would take
state the key variables to be kept constant
draw a suitable table, with column headings, to show how you would display your readings (you are not required to enter any readings in the table)
explain how you would use the results to reach a conclusion
